attributes.style: position: absolute; width: 586px; height: 65px; z-index: 4; left: 200px; top: 327px;

steps.value: [e] this OODA loop

steps.name: h2
steps.value: WAT?

value.name: li
value.value: [e] - just for my game of words ;)

value.name: li
value.value: OODA loop - refers to the decision cycle of observe, orient, decide, and act, developed by military strategist and USAF Colonel John Boyd which often applied to learning processes (wikipedia)

steps.name: notes
steps.value: Spanish, Polish, Yedish, German, English

attributes.style: width: 429px; height: 283px; max-height: none; max-width: none; position: absolute; z-index: 4; left: 269px; top: -80px;

steps.name: h2
steps.value: What is "this"?

steps.name: p
steps.value: When a function is created, a keyword called "this" is created, and bound to the object in which the function operates (execution context object)

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 302px; max-height: none; max-width: none;
width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: For a raw function invocation, the value of "this" will be the "global" or "window" object

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: For a strict mode raw function, the value of "this" will be undefined

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: Method calls assign "this" to the object from which they are called

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: Defining a function on an object, does not mean the function will be invoked on that object

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: And Again, For a strict mode raw function, the value of "this" will be undefined

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: When a function is used as a constructor, the value of "this" within that function becomes a new object instance, of the "type" that the function represents

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;
width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: .call and .apply overrides the value of "this" for the execution

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: ES5 .bind allows you to set the context of a function without invoking it

steps.name: p
steps.value: We can use .bind-and-replace technique with constructor functions

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: The use of .bind allows us to force override the value of "this" for any function in JavaScript when we need to

steps.name: p
steps.value: .bind can be also used for binding argument values

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;

steps.name: p
steps.value: But which one is stronger???

attributes.style: width: 916px; height: 692px; max-height: none; max-width: none;
width: 429px; height: 283px; max-height: none; max-width: none; position: absolute; z-index: 4; left: 269px; top: 0;

steps.name: h2

attributes.style: position: absolute; width: 886px; height: 65px; z-index: 4; left: 50px; top: 320px;

steps.value: So be careful and understand when to use the context forced override given by .bind!

steps.name: h2
steps.value: Wrap Up:

value.name: li
value.value: Raw function: "this" = global context OR undefined (for strict mode)

value.name: li
value.value: Object with method: "this" = the object from which the method is called

value.name: li
value.value: Constructor function: "this" = a new object instance, of the "type" that the function represents

value.name: li
value.value: .call and .apply: "this" = an argument passed at invokation

value.name: li
value.value: .bind method: "this" = an argument passed at construction to generate a new function

steps.name: p
steps.value: One last (simple by now) quiz
